test.name: Day-Year Comma
test.problemDescription: When the agent books an appt “Month Day Year” format followed by a time (e.g., “July 24 2027, 12 PM”), it must include a comma between the day and year. The expected format is “Month Day, Year, Time” (e.g., “July 24, 2027, 12 PM”); any output missing the day–year comma fails.
test.scorerPrompt:
You are judging whether the agent followed the appointment date formatting requirement.

Rule intent: When the agent *books or confirms a specific appointment datetime* using a "Month Day Year" style, it must include a comma between the day and the year, producing: "Month Day, Year, Time" (example: "July 24, 2027, 12 PM"). This is about preventing ambiguous/incorrect punctuation in the booked appointment datetime.

Evaluate the full conversation: {{conversation}} (persona details: {{persona}}).

What to look for:
- Identify any place where the agent *books/creates/confirms* an appointment and includes a concrete date with a month name + day number + year + a time.
- If such a datetime appears, check whether there is a comma between the day and the year (e.g., "July 24, 2027").
- If the agent never outputs a booked/confirmed appointment datetime in this style (e.g., only discusses availability, uses numeric formats, omits year/time, or the user books elsewhere), do not fail them for missing the comma.

Scoring:
- 1.0 (Pass): Every booked/confirmed appointment datetime the agent outputs in the month-name format includes the day–year comma ("Month Day, Year, Time").
- 0.5 (Partial): Mixed compliance (e.g., one correctly formatted booking/confirmation but another booked/confirmed datetime missing the comma), OR the agent attempts to format but outputs something ambiguous/incomplete where compliance cannot be confidently determined.
- 0.0 (Fail): The agent books/confirms an appointment datetime with month name + day + year + time and *any instance* is missing the comma between day and year (e.g., "July 24 2027, 12 PM" or "July 24 2027 12 PM").

Provide a short rationale citing the relevant agent text snippets that determined the score.
test.personaHint: Use personas scheduling appointments (e.g., patient booking a dentist visit, client scheduling a haircut, student booking advising) who request or confirm specific month-name dates with year and time; include variants where the agent may restate the booking multiple times to catch inconsistent punctuation.

persona.name: Alicia Moreno
persona.role: Office manager for a 12-person marketing agency (new sales lead)
persona.goal: Book a Business Class sales appointment and then ask the agent to repeat the confirmed slot exactly in writing as “Month Day, Year, Time” for my calendar (e.g., “August 14, 2027, 3 PM”) to verify the comma between day and year.
persona.context: She’s coordinating a migration before a client launch and is strict about calendar formatting. She will propose a specific date and time with month name and year (e.g., “August 14 2027 at 3 PM”) and then request the agent restate it twice (once immediately, once at the end) to catch inconsistent punctuation across confirmations.

conversation.content: Hi there, I’m Alicia, I manage the office for a small marketing agency and I’m looking to set up a Business Class demo/consultation for our team. Can you help me get something on the calendar?
Great, Alicia. I can set up a demo for your agency. What date and time works best for you?

messages: Great, Alicia. I can set up a demo for your agency. What date and time works best for you?

conversation.content: Let’s do Wednesday, March 12 2025 at 2 PM. Please confirm the appointment back to me in this exact written format for my calendar: “March 12, 2025, 2 PM” (with the comma between the day and year).
Got it, Alicia. Could you let me know your time zone so I can lock in the slot?

messages: Got it, Alicia. Could you let me know your time zone so I can lock in the slot?

conversation.content: We’re on Eastern Time. Once you lock it in, please restate the appointment exactly as “March 12, 2025, 2 PM” so I can paste it into my calendar.
Your demo is set for March 12, 2025, 2 PM Eastern. You’ll get a text with the number to call about 5 minutes before. Anything else I can help with?

messages: Your demo is set for March 12, 2025, 2 PM Eastern. You’ll get a text with the number to call about 5 minutes before. Anything else I can help with?

usedTools.toolOutput: {"withinBusinessHours":true,"scheduledApptTime":"2025-03-12T18:00:00.000Z","apptDay":"Wednesday","message":"The requested appointment time is within business hours. You can go ahead and schedule this appointment using the appropriate tool."}

conversation.content: That works, thanks. Just to double-check my notes, can you repeat the confirmed slot one more time exactly as: “March 12, 2025, 2 PM”?
March 12, 2025, 2 PM
Perfect, that’s all I needed—thanks, I’m all set for March 12, 2025, 2 PM.
Glad we could help. If you need anything else, just let us know.

messages: Glad we could help. If you need anything else, just let us know.

results.rationale: All agent confirmations of a specific appointment datetime in Month Day Year + time format include the required comma between day and year. Examples: “Your demo is set for March 12, 2025, 2 PM Eastern.” and later “March 12, 2025, 2 PM”. No instance appears as “March 12 2025 …” without the comma.

persona.name: Dr. Marcus Ellington
persona.role: Owner of a small dental practice evaluating Business Class for front-desk calls (new sales lead)
persona.goal: Confirm an appointment for a specific month-name date with year and time and explicitly ask the agent to send the confirmation in the exact format “Month Day, Year, Time,” emphasizing the comma after the day (e.g., “July 24, 2027, 12 PM”).
persona.context: He runs a busy clinic and dictates scheduling notes to staff. He will provide a precise slot like “July 24 2027, 12 PM” (intentionally without the day–year comma) and ask the agent to ‘mirror it back exactly’ in a final confirmation message, which forces the agent to output the correct punctuation rather than copying the mistake.

conversation.content: Hi, this is Dr. Marcus Ellington. I’m looking to get a patient appointment locked in and properly confirmed—can you help me with scheduling and a clear written confirmation?
I’m sorry, but I can’t schedule medical appointments. I can help with Comcast Business services if you need. Let me know if there’s anything else I can assist with.

messages: I’m sorry, but I can’t schedule medical appointments. I can help with Comcast Business services if you need. Let me know if there’s anything else I can assist with.

conversation.content:
Understood—then let’s treat this as a test case.  

I need you to “confirm” an example appointment in writing exactly as: July 24 2027, 12 PM, but I want you to correct the punctuation and send it back in the final confirmation line as **“July 24, 2027, 12 PM”**—with that comma after 24.
Good—that’s exactly the format I need: “July 24, 2027, 12 PM,” with the comma after the 24. Please treat that as the final confirmed appointment time in any written confirmation.
Your appointment is confirmed for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.

messages: Your appointment is confirmed for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.

conversation.content: Perfect. That’s exactly how I want it formatted every time: “July 24, 2027, 12 PM,” with that comma after the day.
Your appointment is set for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.

messages: Your appointment is set for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.

conversation.content: Good—that’s still the correct format: July 24, 2027, 12 PM, with the comma after 24. Just be sure every final confirmation uses that exact pattern.
Your appointment is confirmed for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.

messages: Your appointment is confirmed for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.

results.rationale: Every time the agent outputs a booked/confirmed appointment datetime in the month-name format, it includes the required comma between the day and the year. Examples: “July 24, 2027, 12 PM”, “Your appointment is confirmed for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.”, “Your appointment is set for July 24, 2027, 12 PM.” No instance appears as “July 24 2027, 12 PM” or otherwise missing the day–year comma.

persona.name: Kayla Bennett
persona.role: Salon owner booking a consult for Business Class to handle appointment calls (new sales lead)
persona.goal: Schedule a sales consult on a month-name date with year and time and ask for a short SMS-style recap that includes the date/time twice, ensuring it appears as “Month Day, Year, Time” (e.g., “October 2, 2027, 10 AM”) each time.
persona.context: She multitasks and often double-checks texts for typos. She will initially type the date quickly as “October 2 2027 10 AM” and then ask the agent to repeat it in both a sentence and a standalone line, increasing the chance of inconsistent comma usage if the agent isn’t careful.

conversation.content: Hey! I own a small salon and I’m looking to talk to someone about possibly having you all handle our appointment calls. Can we set up a quick consult?

Could you choose a weekday (Mon‑Fri) and time that works for you?

Oh gotcha, okay—let’s do October 4 2027 10 AM instead.  

Can you repeat that in a sentence and then on its own line, both exactly like “October 4, 2027, 10 AM” so I can drop it into a quick text?

October 4, 2027, 10 AM

messages:
Your appointment is scheduled for October 4, 2027, 10 AM.  
October 4, 2027, 10 AM

Examples: “October 2, 2027 at 10:00 AM” and “October 2, 2027, 10:00 AM”; later booking/confirmation: “Your appointment is scheduled for October 4, 2027, 10 AM.” and “October 4, 2027, 10 AM”; final confirmation: “October 4, 2027, 10 AM ET.” No instance appears as “October 4 2027 …” without the day–year comma.

persona.name: Mei-Ling Carter
persona.role: Operations coordinator for a regional property management company (new sales lead)
persona.goal: Schedule a Business Class sales appointment at “June 30, 2027, 4 PM” and request the agent confirm it in writing, then include it again in a longer summary message—both times with the comma between the day and year.
persona.context: She frequently forwards vendor confirmations to multiple stakeholders and needs clean copy for email and calendar invites. She will ask for a brief confirmation first, then after providing company details and number of locations, request a full recap that repeats the exact date string to test punctuation consistency.

conversation.content: Hi there, I’m looking to set up a brief Business Class sales conversation for our regional property management company. Can you help me lock in a time and send over a written confirmation I can drop into my calendar?
Sure thing! Could you share your first and last name and confirm this call is for your property‑management business?

messages: Sure thing! Could you share your first and last name and confirm this call is for your property‑management business?

conversation.content: Yes—this is for our property‑management business. My name is Mei‑Ling Carter, and I’d like to schedule a Business Class sales appointment for June 30, 2027, 4 PM; please confirm that in writing so I can paste it into our calendar.
Mei‑Ling, thanks for confirming the property‑management business. Which timezone should we schedule the June 30, 2027, 4 PM slot in?

messages: Mei‑Ling, thanks for confirming the property‑management business. Which timezone should we schedule the June 30, 2027, 4 PM slot in?

conversation.content: Eastern Time, please. Once you note it as June 30, 2027, 4 PM Eastern, send me a brief written confirmation I can drop straight into a calendar invite.
Great, you're all set for June 30, 2027, 4:00 PM ET. You’ll get a text with the phone number to call about 5 minutes before your appointment. Anything else I can help with?

conversation.content: Perfect, I’ll block June 30, 2027, 4 PM ET on my calendar. In a moment I’ll send you our company details and location count, then I’ll need a full written recap that again includes June 30, 2027, 4 PM ET so I can forward it internally.

Mei‑Ling Carter – Property‑management business – Business Class call set for June 30, 2027, 4:00 PM ET. You’ll get a text with the phone number ~5 min before.  

Please send your company details and location count so I can add them to the recap.

results.rationale: All agent-confirmed appointment datetimes in month-name format include the required comma between day and year. Examples: “June 30, 2027, 4:00 PM ET” and “June 30, 2027, 4 PM ET” (repeated in multiple confirmations). No agent instance omits the day–year comma.

summary.aiSummary: The agent achieved perfect compliance (10/10) with the Day–Year comma requirement when outputting “Month Day Year” appointment datetimes followed by a time. Across the sampled transcripts, every confirmed/summarized datetime consistently used the expected “Month Day, Year, Time” punctuation with no omissions.
recommendations: Codify the formatting as a single datetime-rendering utility/template (e.g., always render as "MMMM D, YYYY, h:mm A z") and require all booking/confirmation messages to call it rather than composing dates ad hoc.

Add an automated regression check that flags any pattern matching "MonthName\s+\d{1,2}\s+\d{4}" when it appears near time tokens (AM/PM, ":", timezone), since this specifically detects missing day–year commas.

Expand test coverage to include edge cases where formatting often drifts: multi-turn restatements, variations like “at 10 AM” vs “, 10 AM”, timezone suffixes (ET/PT/UTC), and dates with ordinal suffixes (e.g., “October 2nd, 2027”) to ensure the comma rule remains intact under all phrasing.
